unit_learning_outcomes.description: Identify and access existing large scale corpora currently available (e.g. Brown, Bank of English, ICE, BNC, Kolhapur, GloWbe, Google Books Corpus, CHILDS, sign language corpora, disordered discourse corpora, etc)
Communicate coherent and advanced knowledge of essential principles, techniques and skills in corpus development and research
Apply key linguistic concepts, such as dialect, text, register/genre, strata, strata and units in language, to the design of empirical, corpus-based, research.
Design a corpus for linguistic research
Operate some computational tools to examine and analyse linguistic patterns in corpora
Produce and clearly communicate robust, quantitative linguistic findings as evidence for a linguistic argument
Apply corpus research methods to the study of language in a variety of contexts and to a variety of linguistic problems

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Readings and tasks in preparation for class

assessments.assessment_title: Corpus development project (including 750 word description of parameters of the corpus)
assessments.description: Students develop a corpus of their own, and relate it to a clearly articulated research question
Students produce a research study, based on either an existing corpus or one they have developed themselves  (3000-3500 words)
Students summarize and review a selection of corpus- based research (1500 words, based on 5 articles)

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: Most linguistic research requires that a researcher develop or access a corpus of naturally occurring text. This unit introduces students to the techniques and concepts in building, annotating and interrogating a corpus. It explores the use of corpus and computation tools in a variety of contexts such as lexicography, language description, language teaching, translation and interpreting, natural language processing, sign language studies, child language development, multimodal discourse studies, and disordered discourse. The unit examines the complementarity between computers and human beings in corpus-based research. Students will be introduced to key terms for corpus development, including dialect, text, register, strata, as well as units in language. Students in this unit will receive training in, and free access to, computational tools for corpus annotation, query and analysis. The unit will be taught by staff members with expertise in diverse areas relating to corpus linguistics.
